title: GPTeach: Interactive TA Training with GPT Based Students
description:
Julia M. Markel, Steven G. Opferman, James A. Landay, Chris Piech. GPTeach: Interactive TA Training with GPT Based Students. ACM Conference on Learning at Scale, 2023.

Interactive and realistic teacher training is hard to scale. What if we could make the teacher training experience more engaging and, as a downstream effect, reduce the potential for harm that teachers-in-training could inflict on students? We present GPTeach, an interactive chat-based teacher training tool that allows novice teachers to practice with simulated students. We performed two studies to evaluate GPTeach, and in this paper, we provide quantitative results and qualitative observations to inform future work in this area.

title: Eli's Places: College Football's Fantastic Finishes (Ep. 9)
description: Eli Manning and ESPN+ invited members of the LSJUMB to discuss, analyze, and reenact The Play.

title: All About That Bass
description: As an audition for a virtual musical, I used the list of instruments to arrange, perform, and produce my own take on Meghan Trainor's 'All About That Bass.'

title: Volunteer Notetaker
description: At Stanford, some disability accomodations give a student access to notes taken by other students, for whatever reason. My job is then to take and upload neat and comprehensive notes for each class session. You're not supposed to know who is getting the accomodations, but one time a classmate told me they really like the way I take notes, so...

title: Peer Technology Specialist
description: For a short time, I worked at a help desk diagnosing software, hardware, and networking problems for students and Stanford affiliates. Then we got sent home for COVID, which made that really hard. But it was interesting while it lasted!

title: Server
description:
(Not to be confused with the type of computer with the same name.)

The summer after graduating high school, I got a job in the dining room of the senior living facility where my grandparents lived. It was really fun, I learned a lot, and I got to know a bunch of really cool people.

title: Concierge
description:
I took time off from school during the pandemic, and one of the things I did was work as a concierge (read: receptionist with extra credit) in an old folks' home. It was so fun to get to be so involved with my residents, and to have the opportunity to do lots of little things to improve the lives of residents, staff, and family members alike.

Because of the work I did screening visitors and tracking vaccinations, I was also technically known as the 'Infection Control Specialist,' which is a cool and fun title.

photos.alt: Me with one of my residents

title: Axis o' Rhythm
description: As the section leader for ABF Drumz, I got to play the biggest, funnest drum. I taught drum lessons and led rehearsals, did a bunch of composing, arranging, and transcribing, and organized all our equipment. More importantly, I got to foster community for my sectionees, watch friendships form and flourish between new and returning members, and advocate for the interests and concerns of my section members in staff, leadership, and director meetings.

photos.alt: A screenshot from the Oregon State Band Instagram account, centered on me with 'Go Beavs' written on my drum, captioned 'we see you'

title: External Relationz
description: During the pandemic, the LSJUMB overhauled its membership, staff, and leadership structure, in addition to replacing its entire suite of governing documents and processes. I co-chaired the committee in charge of this process, had a hand in deciding most policies, and wrote significant portions of the new governing documents, in addition to my nominal task of interfacing with alums, other student groups, and any other outside parties interested in the Band.

title: The Time I Was Iron Man
description: For a football game, the section leaders dressed up as the Avengers. I got to be Iron Man, a role I took very seriously: I designed and built my own arc reactor. It's dope as hell.

title: Transgender, Gender-Variant & Intersex Pro Bono Project
description: Working with the Stanford Law School, I narrated a series of videos clarifying the name and gender marker change process in California. I'm not sure if the videos were ever published, since I can't find them anywhere, but I did film them!

title: Gaieties 2021: Le-Land!
description: I was the head writer for Gaieties 2021, Stanford's annual musical comedy. I hired and led a team of eight staff writers to develop a full-length script and worked with the composers and lyricist to craft songs to deepen the characters and emotions. I was responsible for the overall vision and tone of the show. I also played percussion in the orchestra.

images.alt: Text: "Why does the drummer have a little protective shield around him? Is he dangerous?" (-Elisabeth) "Naughty drummer boys get put in the naughty drummer cage" (-Hannah)

title: Gaieties 2022: Cardinal Sin
description: I played percussion in the orchestra for Gaieties 2022, Stanford's annual musical comedy.

title: Gaieties 2020: Unprecedented Times
description: I was the music director for Gaieties 2020, aka "Zoom Gaieties." I originally signed on to hire and conduct the orchestra for an in-person show, but when the pandemic hit, we had to pivot to a virtual format and I became more of a music facilitator. I picked, transcribed, and re-arranged historic songs from old Gaieties shows, and recruited musicians to record themselves playing the parts.

images.alt: The logo for Gaieties 2020, a rainbow flag overlaid with the name of the show

title: Tony Awards Show
description: Ram's Head Theatrical Society was approached by the Tony Awards to submit a short video shown at the 74th annual live ceremony.

images.alt: A group of students dresses in colorful, vibrant and eccentric clothing and strikes a spirited pose.

title: Gaieties 2019: Midterm: Impossible Ghost Proto-Cal
description: I played percussion in the orchestra for Gaieties 2019, Stanford's annual musical comedy.

title: Pippin
description:
I played percussion in the orchestra for Ram's Head's production of Pippin. Or rather, I would have, had the show not been cancelled due to the pandemic.
Don't tell MTI, but I still have my libretto, since it got packed up with my dorm room and kept by Stanford for eight months.

title: La Llorona
description: I played percussion in the orchestra for Ram's Head's virtual production of La Llorona, an original musical by Obed de la Cruz. The show was performed in Spanish and English, and was a collaboration with BLACKstage.

title: Heathers
description: I played percussion and provided ensemble vocals for Ram's Head's (virtual) production of Heathers. Notably, we were the first to work with the original creators of the musical to produce an official, license-able script with a female J.D.

images.alt: J.D. and Veronica looking at each other, clearly green-screened into a living room

title: Dream Role Cabaret
description: I sang in Ram's Head's Dream Role Cabaret, a virtual concert where students performed songs from roles they would love to play. I sang 'Corner of the Sky' from Pippin, a show we were supposed to put on a year earlier.

title: A Chorus Line
description: My on-stage debut was as Mark in our production of A Chorus Line. As someone who had never danced, it was probably a poor choice for a first show, but I had a lot of fun and learned a lot! I've never been so flexible in my life.

images.alt: Val, performing with the auditionees lined up behind her
Me, in a blue tank top and navy sweatpants, with my hands clasped in prayer
the cast huddled together, looking at the camera, dresses in sparkly gold outfits

title: Little Shop of Horrors
description:
I played auxiliary percussion in the orchestra for Ram's Head's production of Little Shop of Horrors. Notably, our music director neglected to acquire instruments for me until the week of the show, so I was sight-reading opening night. What a time!
There's always time for dental hygiene, Seymour!

title: The 25th Annual Putnam County Spelling Bee
description: I played percussion for the Stanford Light Opera Company's production of The 25th Annual Putnam County Spelling Bee.

images.alt: The cast of The 25th Annual Putnam County Spelling Bee

title: Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street
description: I was the principal percussionist for the Stanford Light Opera Company's production of Sweeney Todd. I played a lot of different instruments, including a lot of different types of drums, a lot of different types of cymbals, and a lot of different types of metal things that you hit with other metal things.

images.alt: The cast of Sweeney Todd, clasped hands raised in a bow

title: Rodgers and Hammerstein's Cinderella
description: I was the assistant music director and percussionist for BLACKstage's production of Cinderella. I transcribed and arranged a song which we added to the show, set up audio equipment for the orchestra, and trained under the technical director to build pieces of the set. Everyone involved was so talented and so kind. It was incredibly fun and my favorite show at Stanford.

images.alt: Prince Chistopher and Cinderella, touching foreheads

title: BATS Improv
description: Occasionally, I perform as a musical improvisor with BATS Improv, a professional improv theater in San Francisco. The group has a longstanding history with the Stanford Improvisors, and it's been a great joy to get to play with SImps of yore.

title: 2023 RESNA Student Design Challenge Winner
description: I was a member of the Stanford team that won first runner-up in the Student Design Challenge put on by the Rehabilitation Engineering and Assistive Technology Society of North America (which is a mouthful). Our project, DUG, was a device co-designed with a community member to help her educate the public about service dog etiquette.

images.alt: our four team members crouched around a service dog

title: Miscast Cabaret
description: I was the music director for SLOCO's Miscast Cabaret, a performance in which students sang songs from roles they could never be cast in. I hired musicians, coordinated, planned, and led rehearsals with orchestra and singers, and arranged and transposed over a dozen songs. I also played the drums in the orchestra, and sang 'One Perfect Moment' from Bring It On. It was an incredible amount of work, but it was SO rewarding to finally pull the show.

title: Greg & Friends Improv
description: I performed as a musical improvisor with Greg & Friends improv at the Pear Theater in Mountain View. It was very last minute, and they had never had a percussion improvisor, so it was really improvised.

title: First Night at the Opera / Edges
description: I was the principal percussionist (timpani and drum set) for the music department's double bill of First Night at the Opera (composed by Giancarlo Aquilanti) and Edges (composed by Benj Pasek and Justin Paul). I orchestrated three songs in the Edges song cycle.

images.alt: The leads of First Night at the Opera

title: Yakuman Chance
description: At the last minute, I was pulled in to stage manage the Theater Lab's production of Yakuman Chance, an original play by Jayda Alvarez. I made sure company members were on time and on schedule, worked with the set and costume designers to acquire pieces, and wrote the tech cues for the script. I also built the setpiece and (for one night only) operated the light board.

images.alt: The four leads, huddled around a scrapbook

title: Percussion Instructor
description: I was hired by a San Francisco high school to turn seven non-musicians into a drumline. I wrote music, taught lessons, assisted the directors at performances, chose and maintained equipment, and occasionally played with the students.

title: International Collegiate Programming Contest (2021)
description: I participated in the North America Qualifier on a team of two. We solved four problems in five hours, and were ranked #298.

title: Stanford High Performance Computing Center
description: I began working for the HPCC my freshman year at Stanford. My favorite thing was getting to set up a new system we received as a hand-me-down from a national lab. Mostly, I wrote documentation and user guides for a variety of topics and audiences and maintained our internal and external websites. I also got loaned out for website consulting to outside research groups. One time I threw together a super basic graphic that my boss loves and now uses all the time, which is fun.

photos.alt: a graphic I made for the HPCC, representing that it is the intersection of industry, learning, teaching, and research

title: External Relationz
description: During the pandemic, the LSJUMB overhauled its membership, staff, and leadership structure, in addition to replacing its entire suite of governing documents and processes. I co-chaired the committee in charge of this process, had a hand in deciding most policies, and wrote significant portions of the new governing documents, in addition to my nominal task of interfacing with alums, other student groups, and any other outside parties interested in the Band.

title: Stanford Improvisors (SImps)
description: I was a member of the Stanford Improvisors, a student-run improv group. I performed as a musical and lighting improvisor, directed formats, and taught workshops. I was a co-president for one year and financial officer for two years.

images.alt: Me during a show. I'm making eye contact with the piano player.
a group of six improvisors on stage, in various poses. I am in the background, looking at them intently

title: Thoroughly Modern Millie
description: The summer after I graduated high school, I played auxiliary percussion for Summer Stock Stage's production of Thoroughly Modern Millie. They had never had student musicians before, so they didn't pay me :( but it was still fun! We got to play at the Indiana Repertory Theatre, which was cool.

title: Sociology Research
description: I worked on several projects at Stanford's VMware Women's Leadership Innovation Lab. I helped design and develop what I'm told is a methodological innovation in collecting digital trace data during online survey experiments, which has been used in several papers.

title: Pilot
description: In CS 377Q: Designing for Accessibility, my team went through the design thinking process to develop a Wizard of Oz prototype. Our project, Pilot, was a variety of Zoom enhancements to empower women with ADHD to better manage distractions during online meetings. We conducted user interviews and conducted iterative testing.
